awd_abstract_narration:
Traditionally, the process to make a components from ceramic powders or clays requires firing (sintering) in a furnace at high temperatures for a long time (many hours or days), a costly process that consumes a large amount of energy.  A new process known as "flash sintering" involves running electrical current directly through the piece, to densify the ceramic and produce a usable component in a matter of seconds.  Initial studies show that many types of ceramics can be fired this way, but these studies have focused on single phase materials, while practical applications often require multiple phases made of different types of ceramics.  This award supports fundamental research to investigate how the electrical and thermal behavior of each component of a multi-phase ceramic responds to flash sintering.  This work will lead to new understanding of the flash sintering process, which will allow for lower cost, higher efficiency processing and manufacture of these critical materials. The processing and the strength of these materials will be studied, to ensure that the components made by this new process are comparable to or better than those made by traditional methods.  The scientific results of the project are integrated into video modules for outreach to elementary and middle school children, to demonstrate the ways that scientists and engineers are studying methods to save energy while making new materials. 

Multiple phases are often required for ceramic components in order to improve mechanical strength, enhance thermal conductivity, and increase thermal shock resistance. In contrast to  conventional sintering approaches which expend significant energy heating the sample and furnace cavity, a high applied electric field with current flowing through the sample can be used to densify oxide ceramics in air and without applied pressure and at much lower temperatures. This research program will evaluate how the direct application of electric fields can be used to flash sinter multiphase ceramic powder compacts.  Multicomponent oxide systems with phases of varying electrical/ionic and thermal conductivity are used to determine the role of these material properties in promoting flash sintering. This information is used to create compositional design parameters to optimize flash sintering via incorporation of minor phases.  Mechanical properties of flash sintered multiphase ceramic composites are compared to conventional sintered materials to evaluate any differences, with microstructural characterization by electron microscopy.

por.por_cntn:
A novel method (flash sintering) of using a direct applied electric field for the firing of ceramics parts containing multiple types of materials was investigated.  This technique greatly speeds up the firing process used to make dense and non-porous ceramics and hence the name flash sintering.  Using flash sintering (firing) means that parts do not have to be held at a high temperature for a long time as with conventional firing of ceramics, so this method has the potential to provide significant cost and energy savings for the manufacturing of many ceramic products.    

     One issue is that a number of technical ceramics are difficult to flash sinter (alumina and spinel for example).  The major goal of this specific project was to develop an understanding of whether the use of multiple types of ceramics (phases) in a ceramic part would enhance flash sintering (firing), even if the individual components are difficult to flash. In addition, another thrust was understanding how the strength and hardness (mechanical properties) of flash sintered materials compared to conventional sintered ceramics to determine if the flash sintering process was competitive. A third goal was the training of graduate students and undergraduate researchers, and to promote outreach on the work we are conducting to educate the public on the impact on saving energy for materials processing can have on our world.

     Flash sintering and mechanical properties of fabricated materials were explored for several technical ceramic systems including alumina/spinel/zirconia, alumina/spinel, alumina/monazite and monazite/zirconia. It was found that ceramics with low thermal conductivity and low ionic conductivity were very difficult to flash by themselves, but when two different phases of these difficult to flash materials were combined, flash sintering would occur.  The role of defects at the interface between two different ceramics is a critical aspect that allows flash sintering to occur in these composite systems.

     This research found that by tailoring the flash sintering parameters (voltage, current, time, temperature), it was possible to make fully dense, fine grained, three-phase composites of ZrO2, Al2O3 and MgAl2O4 with improved mechanical properties compared to conventional sintering. The process of flash sintering two phase Al2O3 and MgAl2O4 (spinel) was demonstrated to generate supersaturated solid solutions of spinel in seconds that typically can only be achieved by using an ultrahigh temperature furnace for long times.  

     Novel intertwined (eutectic) microstructures of two high temperature ceramics (Al2O3 and LaPO4) were synthesized by flash and a phase diagram proposed for the system Al2O3-LaPO4.   The mechanical properties of the eutectic microstructures made by flash were characterized and found superior compared to polycrystalline microstructures with the two phases that could be obtained by conventional sintering (firing).  

     The results of this study show that flash sintering when applied to ceramic composites has promise as a quick and energy efficient method to sinter complex systems as well as the potential to forming unique phases and novel microstructures that can have superior mechanical properties.

     A part of the outreach for this grant, over 40 high school students and their families were involved in two summers of Materials CAMPs, where they were exposed to the discipline of Materials Science & Engineering, and learned about flash sintering and scanning electron microscopy. These programs were directed by the PI at UC Irvine with help from the two graduate students primarily supported on this grant. These two PhD students trained on this grant have graduated and are now are working in R&D positions in the U.S.A.
